name: Benthic Predatory
description: Large predatory fishes play an important role in marine ecosystems, but overexploitation is gradually diminishing this role/Estimates from 2003 indicate that large predatory fish communities were depleted by at least 90% over the past 50-100 years/These families are particularly good indicators of composition, condition and diversity because:/They are all taxonomically well documented and relatively easy to identify underwater/They include ‘core’ reef species and collectively they comprise more than 50% of the observable fishes/Most of these families are targeted by local fishing pressure/Many are flagship species and so are important for tourism/The strongest responses to MPAs in the Philippines have been found in predatory fishes (groupers and breams) and butterflyfish

name: Emperor Bream
description: They are benthopelagic, consuming invertebrates and small fishes/Some species have molariform teeth which they use to eat shelled invertebrates/Heavily targeted by fishermen

name: Humpnose Bigeye
description: Sandy reef slopes/Max Length 60cm/Solitary or groups

name: Longface
description: Outer slopes/Max Length 100cm/Solitary

name: Monocle
description: Sandy flats/Max Length 30cm/Solitary or small groups

name: Grouper
description: The giant grouper can reach 2.7m, although many species are small, in some cases <10cm/Naturally rare and very heavily fished in all of its range/All are carnivore, typically ambush predators, although Anthias typically feed on zooplankton

name: Barramundi Cod
description: Silty areas/Max Length 70cm/Solitary and reclusive

name: Blacksaddle Coral
description: Outer reefs/Max Length 125cm/Solitary

name: Bluespotted
description: Sheltered slopes/Max Length 30cm/Solitary

name: Coral
description: Reef Slopes/Max Length 50cm/Solitary

name: Flagtail
description: Variable habitat/Max Length 28cm/Solitary

name: Highfin
description: Open sand bottoms/Max Length 60cm/Solitary

name: Honeycomb
description: Outer reefs/Max Length 32cm/Solitary

name: Large
description: Coral rich areas/Many larger than 100cm/Solitary

name: Lyretails
description: Outer reefs/Max Length 60cm/Solitary

name: Peacock
description: Outer slopes/Max Length 60cm/Solitary

name: Moorish Idol
description: Lagoon and outer reefs to 180 m/Up to 16 cm/Solitary, in pairs, or groups

name: Snapper
description: Grow to about 1m maximum and found down to 100m depth/Most are active carnivores feeding on crustaceans or other fish (few are plankton feeders)/Many species not yet evaluated for vulnerability status, but are very important commercially

name: Black-Banded
description: Slopes/Max Length 35cm/Solitary or groups

name: Checkered
description: Outer slopes/Max Length 35cm/Solitary or groups

name: Midnight
description: Steep slopes and walls/Max Length 60cm/Solitary or groups

name: Red
description: Outer reefs/Max Length 75cm/Solitary or groups

name: Two-Spot
description: Reef Slopes/Max Length 25cm/Small to large groups

name: Sweetlips
description: Benthic predators eating a variety of worms, crabs and shrimp/Engage with a mutualistic relationship with cleaner gobies, allowing them to feed on their ectoparasites/Good diversity indicators and have many flagship species/They are commonly fished by locals

name: Diagonal-Banded
description: Reef slopes/Max Length 48cm/Solitary or small groups

name: Many-Spotted
description: Reef Ledges/Max Length 72cm/Solitary

name: Oriental
description: Coastal Reefs/Max Length 85cm/Solitary or small groups

name: Ribboned
description: Exposed reefs/Max Length 50cm/Solitary or small groups

name: Triggerfish
description: One of the most successful invertebrate predators/They are sensitive to environmental change making them good indicators for habitat, community and diversity/Very easy to ID and important predator indicators as they feed exclusively on invertebrates

name: Blackpatch
description: Very similar species to Picasso, not to be confused

name: Clown
description: Coral rich slopes/Max Length 50cm/Solitary

name: Orange Lined
description: Coral rich areas/Max Length 30cm/Solitary

name: Picasso
description: Lagoons and reef flats/Max Length 30cm/Solitary or groups

name: Rectangular
description: Very similar species to Picasso, not to be confused

name: Redtoothed
description: Exposed reef slopes/Max Length 40cm/For agregations

name: Scythe
description: Mixed substrates/Max Length 25cm/Solitary

name: Titan
description: Lagoons and outer reefs/Max Length 75cm/Solitary – Known to attack divers

name: Wrasse
description: Typically small fish < 20cm/Efficient carnivores feeding on a wide range of small invertebrates and also important as “cleaner fish”/Good diversity indicators and larger species targeted by fishermen

name: Hog Fish
description: Outer reef slopes/Up to 30cm/Solitary or small groups

name: Humphead
description: Humphead wrasse can reach 2.5m!

name: Moon
description: Outer reef slopes/Max Length 25cm/Solitary or groups

name: Redbreasted
description: Mixed substrates/Max Length 40cm/Solitary

name: Slingjaw
description: Coral rich areas/Max Length 35cm/Solitary

name: Thicklips
description: Mixed substrates/Max Length 60cm/Solitary

name: Tripletail
description: Outer reefs/Max Length 45cm/Solitary

name: Tuskfish
description: Sand and rubble/Up to 50cm/Solitary

name: Butterflyfish
description: Large predatory fishes play an important role in marine ecosystems, but overexploitation is gradually diminishing this role/Estimates from 2003 indicate that large predatory fish communities were depleted by at least 90% over the past 50-100 years/These families are particularly good indicators of composition, condition and diversity because:/They are all taxonomically well documented and relatively easy to identify underwater/They include ‘core’ reef species and collectively they comprise more than 50% of the observable fishes/Most of these families are targeted by local fishing pressure/Many are flagship species and so are important for tourism/The strongest responses to MPAs in the Philippines have been found in predatory fishes (groupers and breams) and butterflyfish

name: Black Backed Butterflyfish
description: Diagonal black lines on white body./Dark black patch at rear of upper body./Black saddle on caudal peduncle./Up to 15 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE./Feeds primarily on Alcyonacian soft corals

name: Chevroned Butterflyfish
description: Numerous chevron markings./Black tail with yellow margin./Up to 18 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE./Feeds practically exclusively on Acropora tabulate corals

name: Eastern Triangle Butterflyfish
description: Gray body with narrow triangular, ‘arrowhead’ markings./Black and yellow stripes on face./Up to 15cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE./Affiliated with large tabulate Acropora corals

name: Eclipse Butterflyfish
description: Bright yellow./Large blue edged black spot in the center of the body./Pair of bright blue lines on the lower body./Black bar through eyes./Up to 18 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Eight Banded Butterflyfish
description: Yellow and Orange body./8 Narrow black bars./Up to 12 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Meyer’s Butterflyfish
description: White to bluish white body./Curving black bands (with kind of M mark)./Encircled by yellowish rim./Up to 18 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Ornate Butterflyfish
description: Bluish white body./Diagonal Orange lines./Up to 18 cm./CORALLIVORES- although only feeding on coral MUCUS

name: Oval-spot Butterflyfish
description: Bright yellow./Large black oval shaped spot on each side./Black vertical band on the eye./Up to 18 cm./FACULTIVE CORALLIVORE

name: Pacific Double Saddle Butterflyfish
description: White body with bright yellow rear./Pair of diffuse dark saddles across back./Black spot on tail base./Up to 15 cm./FACULTIVE CORALLIVORE

name: Pennant Bannerfish
description: White with black band on head, mid body and upper rear body./Yellow upper snout./Long feather-like dorsal fin./Up to 18 cm./FACULTIVE CORALLIVORE

name: Redfin Butterflyfish
description: Very round body./Pale blue stripes often with a faint spot./Borders of dorsal and anal fin red (may appear brown at depth)./Up to 15cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Singular Bannerfish
description: Large fish./Dark grey-black body./Yellow tail./Up to 23 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Spot Banded Butterflyfish
description: Yellow body./Vertical greyish stripes which fade into spots./Up to 12 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Spot-Tail Butterflyfish
description: White body./Diagonal black lines./Black spot on base of tail./Up to 14 cm./OBLIGATE CORALLIVORE

name: Teardrop Butterflyfish
description: White with bright yellow dorsal, anal and ventral fins./Black tear shaped spot on back./Large bulbous snout when adults- robust jaws./Up to 20 cm./CORALLIVORES./Have a relationship with a species of foliose Acropora

name: Black & white Butterflyfish
description: White-black band from nape to pectoral./Vertical or undercut dropoff on outer reefs in 20-80 m./To 14 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Blackfin Coralfish
description: Dark brown bar./Dark brown spot on rear dorsal fin./Reef 2-10 m./To 20 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Blacklip Butterflyfish
description: Rusty brown/orange body./White head with black eye stripe./Black lips./Can have a white band in the middle of the body./Up to 14cm./OMNIVORE

name: Dotted Butterflyfish
description: Yellow with horizontal rown of small black spots./Blue marking on rear snout and nape./Dorsal fin usually trails a thread-like filament./Up to 24 cm./Usually seen in pairs./OMNIVORE

name: Highfin Butterflyfish
description: Looks like orange-banded./Adults LACK SPOT ON DORSAL FIN./Rare shallow species./To 20cm./OMNIVORE

name: Humphead Bannerfish
description: Extended dorsal fin gives body a triangular appearance./Two distinct white bands on dark body./Forehead has indent and hump above the eye./Up to 19cm./OMNIVORE

name: Latticed Butterflyfish
description: Bright yellow body./Crosshatch, ‘lattice’ pattern (like waffle)./Up to 15cm./OMNIVORE

name: Lined Butterflyfish
description: White with vertical lines./Broad black patch on rear body./Black eye bar encloses a white spot on nape./Up to 30 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Long-Beaked Coralfish
description: White with orangey/brown bars./Ocelli on rear dorsal fin./Long beak-like snout./Up to 20cm./Found at Gam Hall (Sawinggrai Bay)./CARNIVORE- small crustaceans

name: Big or Long Nose Butterflyfish
description: Two species that look very similar./Bright yellow body with white and black face./Very long snout./Up to 22cm./OMNIVORE

name: Masked Bannerfish
description: Rear body and fins yellow./Bump on nape./Fin much shorter than Longfin./OMNIVORE

name: Ocellated Coralfish
description: Silvery white, 5 brown-orange bars./Ocellated spot on tail base./Black spot on elevated triangular dorsal fin./To 18 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Orange banded Butterflyfish
description: White with wide brown bars./1 ocellus on rear dorsal fin./Up to 15 cm

name: Panda Butterflyfish
description: Whitish with darker./Diagonal lines./Yellow-Orange Fins./Oval shaped black eye patch and small black spot on nape./Up to 16 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Pyramid Butterflyfish
description: Dark brown head and yellow body with triangular white marking./Often seen in schools./Up to 18cm./PLANKTIVORE

name: Raccoon Butterflyfish
description: Yellow-Orange with dusky back./Black eye patch with./white band behind the eye./Black spot on caudal peduncle./Big diagonal band running from eye to dorsal fin./Up to 21 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Saddled Butterflyfish
description: Blue-gray with blue lines on lower body./Large black saddle on upper rear body./Often displays a rainbow ./coloration on rear dorsal fin./Up to 23 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Schooling or Longfin Bannerfish
description: Two different species which look similar./Long white dorsal fin./Yellow tail./Up to 25 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Speckled Butterflyfish
description: Pale yellow to whitish./Many rows of faint blueish spots./Black edge on anal fin./Up to 13 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Spot nape Butterflyfish
description: White with vertical black lines./Broad black patch on rear body./Black eye bar with separated black patch on nape./Up to 25 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Threadfin Butterflyfish
description: White with chevron pattern./Rear body and tail yellow./Dorsal fin usually trails a thread-like filament./Up to 23 cm./OMNIVORE- diet varies geographically./Scavenger species on diseased or damaged coral

name: Two eyed Butterflyfish
description: White with closely spaced brown bars./Only species with 2 ocelli (spots on rear dorsal and anal fins)./Up to 15 cm./CARNIVORE- barrel sponge

name: Vagabond Butterflyfish
description: Blue/grey lines in distinct ‘V’ shaped pattern on body./Black bars across rear of body and middle of tail./Black eye stripe./Up to 23 cm./OMNIVORE

name: Yellow-backed Butterflyfish
description: White body with grey cross-hatch pattern./Orange/yellow rear section including posterior dorsal fin and tail./Up to 13 cm./OMNIVORE/FACULTIVE CORALLIVORE

name: Yellow-dotted Butterflyfish
description: White with numerous silvery spots in diagonal rows./Similar to black-backed, but black is on FIN not on body./Up to 16 cm./Fairly rare species./CARNIVORE
